docs.title: The Browser Designed for AI Agents
docs.text:
Oryn (Open Runtime for Intentful Navigation) is a browser automation system designed specifically for AI agents. Instead of forcing agents to understand screenshots, parse HTML, or construct complex function calls, Oryn provides a semantic intent language that speaks naturally to how agents think about web interaction.

Installation Quick Start Command Reference GitHub

docs.title: Why Oryn?
docs.text:
Current approaches to browser automation for AI agents fall into predictable failure patterns:

Approach Problem Screenshot/Vision Expensive inference, unreliable text extraction, no understanding of interactive state HTML Parsing Thousands of tokens of markup, complex reasoning about visibility and interactivity Function Calls Rigid schemas, verbose definitions, no tolerance for natural variation

Oryn solves this by design:

Capability Description Semantic Observations Structured descriptions of interactive elements with meaningful labels, types, roles, and states Intent Language Natural, forgiving syntax for expressing actions at the appropriate level of abstraction Consistent Behavior Identical semantics across embedded, headless, and remote modes Token Efficient Minimal verbosity means more context for agent reasoning

docs.title: Three Deployment Modes
docs.text: A single unified binary adapts to any environment: embedded IoT devices, headless cloud servers, or browser extensions for user assistance.

docs.title: Semantic Targeting
docs.text: Agents can reference elements by meaning rather than implementation. Say "click login" instead of hunting for CSS selectors.

docs.title: Pattern Detection
docs.text: Common UI patterns (login forms, search boxes, cookie banners) are automatically recognized and reported to agents.

docs.title: Intent Engine
docs.text: High-level intents like login, search, and accept_cookies encapsulate common workflows, expandable via YAML definitions.

docs.title: Quick Example
docs.text:
Instead of parsing HTML or analyzing screenshots, agents interact naturally:

goto github.com/login
observe

@ github.com/login "Sign in to GitHub"
[1] input/email "Username or email" {required}
[2] input/password "Password" {required}
[3] button/submit "Sign in" {primary}

type 1 "myusername"
type 2 "mypassword"
click 3

The agent sees labeled interactive elements and issues simple commands. No CSS selectors, no XPath, no DOM traversal—just intent.

docs.title: The Three Modes
docs.text:
Mode Binary Engine Best For Embedded oryn-e WPE WebKit IoT, containers, edge (~50MB RAM) Headless oryn-h Chromium Cloud automation, CI/CD (~99% compatibility) Remote oryn-r User's Browser User assistance, authenticated sessions

All three modes share the same protocol, intent language, and Universal Scanner—ensuring consistent behavior regardless of deployment environment.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Get up and running with Oryn:

# Clone and build
git clone https://github.com/dragonscale/oryn.git
cd oryn
cargo build --release -p oryn

# Run in headless mode
./target/release/oryn headless

# In the REPL, navigate and observe
> goto example.com
> observe
> click "More information..."

Complete Quick Start Guide →

docs.title: Concepts
docs.text: This section covers the core concepts and architecture of Oryn.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Oryn is built on several key principles:

  1. Intent Over Implementation — Agents express what they want to do, not how to do it
  2. Semantic Abstraction — Web pages are presented as structured, labeled interactive surfaces
  3. Universal Consistency — The same behavior across all deployment modes
  4. Progressive Intelligence — From atomic commands to high-level intents

docs.title: Core Components
docs.text: graph TD     A[AI Agent] -->|Intent Commands| B[Intent Parser]     B --> C[Intent Engine]     C -->|Atomic Commands| D[Scanner Interface]     D --> E[Universal Scanner]     E -->|JSON Protocol| F[Browser Backend]     F --> G[oryn-h: Chromium]     F --> H[oryn-e: WebKit]     F --> I[oryn-r: Extension]

docs.title: Key Concepts
docs.text:
• :material-layers:{ .lg .middle } Architecture

    How Oryn's layered architecture separates agent concerns from browser complexity.

    :octicons-arrow-right-24: Architecture

  • :material-text-box:{ .lg .middle } Intent Language

    The agent-facing command protocol designed for token efficiency and forgiveness.

    :octicons-arrow-right-24: Intent Language

  • :material-magnify-scan:{ .lg .middle } Scanner Protocol

    The internal JSON protocol between Oryn and the browser-embedded scanner.

    :octicons-arrow-right-24: Scanner Protocol

  • :material-cog:{ .lg .middle } Intent Engine

    How high-level intents are expanded into atomic operations.

    :octicons-arrow-right-24: Intent Engine

  • :material-server:{ .lg .middle } Backend Modes

    The three deployment modes: embedded, headless, and remote.

    :octicons-arrow-right-24: Backend Modes

docs.title: The Universal Scanner
docs.text:
At the heart of Oryn is the Universal Scanner—a JavaScript module that runs inside web pages and understands them the way agents need to.

The scanner: - Identifies all interactive elements - Labels them with simple numeric IDs - Classifies their types (input, button, link, etc.) - Infers their roles (email, password, search, submit) - Reports their states (required, disabled, checked) - Detects common patterns (login forms, search boxes, pagination)

This same scanner code runs in all environments, guaranteeing consistent behavior.

docs.title: Multi-Level Abstraction
docs.text:
Oryn supports commands at different levels of abstraction:

Level Description Example Level 1: Direct Operate on element IDs click 5 Level 2: Semantic Operate on roles/text click "Sign in" Level 3: Intent High-level workflows login "user" "pass" Level 4: Goal Natural language goals (Agent/LLM layer)

Agents can mix levels as needed, using direct commands for precision and intents for common workflows.

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text: Oryn's architecture is designed around a core insight: the scanner is the source of truth. All HTML understanding happens in JavaScript inside the browser; the Rust layer never parses HTML directly.

docs.title: System Layers
docs.text: graph TB     subgraph "Agent Layer"         A[AI Agent]     end      subgraph "Protocol Layer"         B[Intent Parser]         C[Intent Engine]         D[Semantic Resolver]     end      subgraph "Backend Layer"         E[Backend Trait]         F[oryn-h CDP]         G[oryn-e WebDriver]         H[oryn-r WebSocket]     end      subgraph "Scanner Layer"         I[Universal Scanner JS]     end      subgraph "Browser Layer"         J[Chromium]         K[WPE WebKit]         L[User Browser]     end      A -->|Intent Commands| B     B --> C     C --> D     D --> E     E --> F     E --> G     E --> H     F -->|CDP| J     G -->|WebDriver| K     H -->|Extension| L     J --> I     K --> I     L --> I

docs.title: Agent Layer
docs.text:
AI agents communicate with Oryn using the Intent Language. They receive observations, make decisions, and issue commands. Agents never interact with raw browser APIs or HTML.

Key Properties: - Token-efficient command syntax - Semantic observations instead of raw HTML - Multi-level abstraction (direct, semantic, intent)

docs.title: Intent Parser
docs.text: Interprets agent commands with forgiveness for variations: - Case-insensitive commands - Multiple quote styles - Command aliases (e.g., goto = navigate = go to) - Flexible option syntax

docs.title: Intent Engine
docs.text: Transforms high-level intents into atomic operations: - Built-in intents (login, search, accept_cookies, etc.) - Loaded intents from YAML definitions - Multi-step execution with error handling - Success/failure verification

docs.title: Semantic Resolver
docs.text: Translates targets to concrete elements: - Text matching ("Sign in") - Role matching (email, password, submit) - Pattern references (login_form.email) - Fallback chains

docs.title: Backend Trait
docs.text:
A unified Rust trait that all backends implement:

pub trait Backend {
    async fn navigate(&mut self, url: &str) -> Result<()>;
    async fn execute_scanner(&mut self, cmd: ScannerCommand) -> Result<ScannerResponse>;
    async fn screenshot(&mut self) -> Result<Vec<u8>>;
    async fn close(&mut self) -> Result<()>;
}

This abstraction ensures agents can switch modes without changing their logic.

docs.title: oryn-h (Headless)
docs.text:
• Technology: Chrome DevTools Protocol (CDP)
  • Transport: WebSocket
  • Library: chromiumoxide
  • Best for: Cloud automation, CI/CD, maximum compatibility

docs.title: oryn-e (Embedded)
docs.text:
• Technology: WebDriver protocol
  • Transport: HTTP
  • Library: fantoccini
  • Best for: IoT, containers, low-memory environments

docs.title: oryn-r (Remote)
docs.text:
• Technology: Custom WebSocket protocol
  • Transport: WebSocket
  • Client: Browser extension
  • Best for: User assistance, authenticated sessions, debugging

docs.title: Scanner Layer
docs.text:
The Universal Scanner is a JavaScript module injected into all browser contexts:

// Simplified scanner interface
const scanner = {
  scan: () => { /* Returns all interactive elements */ },
  click: (id) => { /* Clicks element by ID */ },
  type: (id, text) => { /* Types into element */ },
  // ... more commands
};

Key Properties: - Byte-for-byte identical across all backends - JSON request/response protocol - Maintains element map for efficient targeting - Detects UI patterns automatically

docs.title: Command Execution
docs.text: sequenceDiagram     participant Agent     participant Parser     participant Engine     participant Backend     participant Scanner     participant Browser      Agent->>Parser: click "Sign in"     Parser->>Engine: ClickCommand(text="Sign in")     Engine->>Backend: scan()     Backend->>Scanner: {cmd: "scan"}     Scanner->>Browser: Query DOM     Browser-->>Scanner: Element data     Scanner-->>Backend: {ok: true, elements: [...]}     Backend-->>Engine: Elements list     Engine->>Engine: Resolve "Sign in" → ID 5     Engine->>Backend: click(5)     Backend->>Scanner: {cmd: "click", id: 5}     Scanner->>Browser: Click element     Browser-->>Scanner: Success     Scanner-->>Backend: {ok: true}     Backend-->>Engine: Success     Engine-->>Parser: ClickResult     Parser-->>Agent: ok click [5]

docs.title: Observation Flow
docs.text: sequenceDiagram     participant Agent     participant Oryn     participant Scanner     participant Browser      Agent->>Oryn: observe     Oryn->>Scanner: {cmd: "scan"}     Scanner->>Browser: Query interactive elements     Browser-->>Scanner: DOM elements     Scanner->>Scanner: Classify types, roles     Scanner->>Scanner: Detect patterns     Scanner-->>Oryn: {elements: [...], patterns: {...}}     Oryn->>Oryn: Format for agent     Oryn-->>Agent: Structured observation

docs.title: Scanner as Source of Truth
docs.text:
HTML parsing should NOT happen in Rust.

If HTML were parsed differently per backend, behavior would diverge. The Universal Scanner eliminates this risk by ensuring all DOM understanding happens in JavaScript.

docs.title: Consistency Guarantees
docs.text: Given the same page state and the same command: - oryn-e, oryn-h, and oryn-r produce identical observations - oryn-e, oryn-h, and oryn-r execute identical actions - oryn-e, oryn-h, and oryn-r report identical results

docs.title: Separation of Concerns
docs.text: Layer Responsibility Agent Decision-making, goal pursuit Protocol Command parsing, intent execution Backend Browser communication Scanner DOM understanding, element classification Browser HTML rendering, JavaScript execution

docs.title: Resource Comparison
docs.text: Mode RAM Binary Size Notes oryn-h ~300MB+ ~15MB Chrome installed separately oryn-e ~50MB ~15MB WPE WebKit libraries oryn-r Zero server ~15MB Runs in user's browser

docs.title: Backend Modes
docs.text: Oryn provides three deployment modes, each optimized for different environments while sharing the same protocol and behavior.

docs.title: Mode Comparison
docs.text: Aspect oryn-e (Embedded) oryn-h (Headless) oryn-r (Remote) Browser Engine WPE WebKit Chromium User's Browser Protocol WebDriver (HTTP) CDP (WebSocket) Custom (WebSocket) RAM Usage ~50MB ~300MB+ Zero (client-side) Compatibility ~95% (WebKit) ~99% (Chromium) ~99% Anti-Bot Bypass Weak Medium Strong Best For IoT, containers Cloud, CI/CD User assistance

docs.title: oryn-e: Embedded Mode
docs.text: oryn embedded --driver-url http://localhost:8080

docs.title: Technology Stack
docs.text:
• Browser: COG (WPE WebKit)
  • Protocol: WebDriver over HTTP
  • Library: fantoccini (Rust WebDriver client)

docs.title: Best For
docs.text:
• Raspberry Pi and IoT devices
  • Resource-constrained containers
  • Alpine Linux deployments
  • Edge computing scenarios
  • Environments where RAM is precious

docs.title: Characteristics
docs.text: Property Value Memory footprint ~50MB Web compatibility ~95% (WebKit) Anti-bot effectiveness Weak (recognizable fingerprint) Self-contained Yes (with WPE libraries)

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
# Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt install cog libwpewebkit-1.0-dev

# Start COG in WebDriver mode
cog --webdriver --port 8080

# Connect Oryn
oryn embedded --driver-url http://localhost:8080

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
IoT Automation Hub 

A Raspberry Pi runs automation agents that need web access.
With ~50MB footprint, plenty of resources remain for the agent itself.

Edge Retail Kiosk 

An in-store kiosk provides voice-controlled web browsing.
Self-contained deployment without Chrome dependency.

docs.title: oryn-h: Headless Mode
docs.text: oryn headless

docs.title: Technology Stack
docs.text:
• Browser: Chromium (headless)
  • Protocol: Chrome DevTools Protocol (CDP)
  • Library: chromiumoxide (Rust CDP client)

docs.title: Best For
docs.text:
• Cloud-based automation
  • CI/CD pipeline testing
  • High-volume web scraping
  • Complex SPA interaction
  • Maximum browser compatibility

docs.title: Characteristics
docs.text: Property Value Memory footprint ~300MB+ Web compatibility ~99% (Chromium) Anti-bot effectiveness Medium (detectable fingerprint) Network interception Yes DevTools integration Yes

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
# Install Chrome/Chromium
sudo apt install chromium-browser

# Run Oryn (auto-detects Chrome)
oryn headless

# Or specify Chrome path
oryn headless --chrome-path /usr/bin/google-chrome

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --chrome-path <PATH> Path to Chrome executable --user-data-dir <DIR> Chrome user data directory --no-headless Run with visible browser window --window-size <WxH> Browser window size --disable-gpu Disable GPU acceleration

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
Cloud Scraping Service 

A system monitors competitor pricing across multiple sites.
Headless Chrome handles complex SPAs reliably.
Network interception captures API responses for analysis.

CI/CD Testing 

Automated tests run against a web application.
Screenshots document any failures.
Same browser as production users ensures compatibility.

docs.title: oryn-r: Remote Mode
docs.text: oryn remote --port 9001

docs.title: Technology Stack
docs.text:
• Browser: User's own browser
  • Protocol: Custom WebSocket
  • Client: Browser extension

docs.title: Best For
docs.text:
• User assistance workflows
  • Demonstrations and teaching
  • Tasks requiring authenticated sessions
  • Anti-bot bypass (real browser fingerprint)
  • Interactive agent assistance

docs.title: Characteristics
docs.text: Property Value Memory footprint Zero (server-side) Web compatibility ~99% (user's browser) Anti-bot effectiveness Strong (real browser) User sessions Yes (access to logged-in state) Visual feedback Yes (user sees actions)

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
1. Install the browser extension:
  2. Chrome: Load unpacked from extension/ directory

  3. Firefox: Load temporary add-on from extension/

  4. Start the remote server: 

    oryn remote --port 9001

  5. Connect from browser:

  6. Click the Oryn extension icon
  7. Enter the server address (e.g., localhost:9001)
  8. Click "Connect"

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --port <PORT> WebSocket server port --host <HOST> Host to bind to

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
Personal Assistant 

An agent helps a user book travel.
Agent has access to user's authenticated sessions.
User watches agent navigate booking sites.
Real browser fingerprint bypasses anti-bot measures.

Interactive Debugging 

Developer watches agent interact with their app.
Can intervene if agent gets stuck.
See exactly what the agent "sees" in real-time.

docs.title: Decision Flowchart
docs.text: graph TD     A[Start] --> B{Need user's sessions?}     B -->|Yes| C[oryn-r Remote]     B -->|No| D{RAM constrained?}     D -->|Yes, <100MB| E[oryn-e Embedded]     D -->|No| F{Need max compatibility?}     F -->|Yes| G[oryn-h Headless]     F -->|No| H{Running on IoT?}     H -->|Yes| E     H -->|No| G

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: Scenario Recommended Mode Cloud automation oryn-h CI/CD testing oryn-h Web scraping oryn-h Raspberry Pi oryn-e Docker container (minimal) oryn-e Edge computing oryn-e User assistance oryn-r Authenticated sessions oryn-r Anti-bot bypass oryn-r Debugging oryn-r

docs.title: Protocol Consistency
docs.text:
All three modes share:

  • Same Intent Language commands
  • Same observation format
  • Same element IDs and targeting
  • Same error codes and responses
  • Same Universal Scanner

Guarantee: Given the same page state and command, all three modes produce identical results.

docs.title: Limitations by Mode
docs.text:
oryn-e: - WebKit may render some pages differently - Some cutting-edge features may lag Chromium - WebDriver has performance overhead

oryn-h: - Headless Chrome has detectable fingerprint - Higher resource requirements - Chrome must be installed separately

oryn-r: - Requires user to install extension - User's browser must remain open - Network dependent (WebSocket) - Cannot operate unattended

docs.title: Intent Engine
docs.text: The Intent Engine is the intelligence layer of Oryn that transforms high-level agent commands into executable atomic operations.

docs.title: Core Principle
docs.text:
The scanner remains simple; the engine provides intelligence.

The Universal Scanner knows only atomic commands: scan, click, type, select. It has no concept of "login" or "checkout." The Intent Engine holds this knowledge, expanding intent commands into sequences of atomic operations.

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text: graph TD     A[Agent Command] -->|"login user pass"| B[Intent Parser]     B --> C[Intent Registry]     C --> D{Intent Found?}     D -->|Yes| E[Intent Executor]     D -->|No| F[Error: Unknown Intent]     E --> G[Pattern Matcher]     G --> H[Step Expansion]     H --> I[Atomic Commands]     I --> J[Scanner Interface]     J --> K[Scanner]

docs.title: Tier 1: Built-in Intents
docs.text:
Compiled into the Rust binary, extensively tested:

Intent Description Syntax login Authenticate with credentials login <user> <pass> logout End authenticated session logout search Submit search query search <query> accept_cookies Dismiss cookie banner accept_cookies dismiss_popups Close modal dialogs dismiss_popups fill_form Fill multiple fields fill_form <data> submit_form Submit current form submit_form scroll_to Scroll element into view scroll_to <target>

docs.title: Tier 2: Loaded Intents
docs.text:
Defined in YAML files, loaded at startup:

Source Path Description Core intents/core/*.yaml Common intents shipped with Oryn Site Packs intents/packs/{domain}/*.yaml Site-specific intents User ~/.oryn/intents/*.yaml User-defined intents

docs.title: Tier 3: Discovered Intents
docs.text: Created by learning during operation, session-scoped by default.

docs.title: Execution Pipeline
docs.text: sequenceDiagram     participant Agent     participant Parser     participant Engine     participant Scanner      Agent->>Parser: login "user" "pass"     Parser->>Engine: LoginIntent(user, pass)     Engine->>Scanner: scan()     Scanner-->>Engine: Elements + Patterns     Engine->>Engine: Resolve login_form pattern     Engine->>Scanner: type(email_id, "user")     Scanner-->>Engine: OK     Engine->>Scanner: type(pass_id, "pass")     Scanner-->>Engine: OK     Engine->>Scanner: click(submit_id)     Scanner-->>Engine: OK + Navigation     Engine->>Engine: Verify: URL changed, no login_form     Engine-->>Parser: LoginResult(success)     Parser-->>Agent: ok login

docs.title: Pipeline Stages
docs.text: Stage Description Parse Extract intent name and parameters Resolve Look up intent definition Plan Scan page, resolve targets, generate steps Execute Run each step, collect results Verify Check success/failure conditions Respond Format response for agent

docs.title: Intent Definition Format
docs.text:
Intent definitions use YAML:

intent: login
version: "1.0"
description: "Authenticate with username/email and password"

parameters:
  - name: username
    type: string
    required: true
  - name: password
    type: string
    required: true

steps:
  - action: type
    target: { role: email }
    text: $username

  - action: type
    target: { role: password }
    text: $password

  - action: click
    target: { role: submit }

  - action: wait
    condition:
      any:
        - url_changed: true
        - pattern_gone: login_form

success:
  conditions:
    - url_changed: true
    - pattern_gone: login_form

failure:
  conditions:
    - text_contains: ["incorrect", "invalid", "wrong"]

docs.title: Target Resolution
docs.text:
Targets can be specified multiple ways:

# By pattern reference
target:
  pattern: login_form.email

# By role
target:
  role: email

# By text
target:
  text: "Sign in"
  match: contains

# By selector (fallback)
target:
  selector: "#email-input"

# With fallback chain
target:
  pattern: login_form.submit
  fallback:
    role: submit
    fallback:
      text_contains: ["sign in", "log in"]

docs.title: Resolution Algorithm
docs.text:
1. Pattern reference → Pattern detected? → Get element ID
2. Role match → Find elements with role → Disambiguate
3. Text match → Find elements with text → Disambiguate
4. Selector → Query DOM → Get element
5. Fallback → Try next target spec
6. Fail → Return TargetNotFound

docs.title: login
docs.text:
Syntax: login <username> <password> [--no-submit] [--wait <duration>]

Execution: 1. Scan page for elements and patterns 2. Locate login form via login_form pattern or heuristics 3. Type username into email/username field 4. Type password into password field 5. Click submit button (unless --no-submit) 6. Wait for navigation or error state

Success Response: 

ok login

# actions
type [1] "user@example.com"
type [2] "••••••••"
click [3] "Sign in"
wait navigation

# changes
~ url: /login → /dashboard
- login_form
+ user_menu

docs.title: search
docs.text:
Syntax: search <query> [--submit enter|click|auto]

Execution: 1. Scan for search form or search input 2. Clear existing content 3. Type search query 4. Submit via Enter key or search button

docs.title: accept_cookies
docs.text:
Syntax: accept_cookies [--reject]

Execution: 1. Scan for cookie_banner pattern 2. Find accept button (or reject if --reject) 3. Click to dismiss 4. Verify banner removal

docs.title: dismiss_popups
docs.text:
Syntax: dismiss_popups [--all] [--type modal|overlay|toast|banner]

Execution: 1. Scan for popup patterns 2. For each detected popup, find close button 3. Click to dismiss 4. Re-scan for newly revealed popups 5. Repeat until no popups remain (max 5 iterations)

docs.title: Step-Level Errors
docs.text: Error Default Behavior Target not found Retry after re-scan Element not visible Scroll into view, retry Element disabled Wait for enabled Click intercepted Use force click Timeout Fail

docs.title: Retry Configuration
docs.text:
options:
  retry:
    max_attempts: 3
    delay: 1s
    on: [target_not_found, element_stale]

docs.title: Multi-Page Flows
docs.text:
Intents can span multiple pages:

intent: complete_checkout
flow:
  start: cart
  pages:
    - name: cart
      url_pattern: ".*/cart.*"
      steps:
        - action: click
          target: { text: "Checkout" }
      next: shipping

    - name: shipping
      url_pattern: ".*/checkout/shipping.*"
      steps:
        - action: intent
          name: fill_shipping
          params: $shipping
      next: payment

    - name: payment
      url_pattern: ".*/checkout/payment.*"
      steps:
        - action: intent
          name: fill_payment
          params: $payment
      next: confirmation

    - name: confirmation
      url_pattern: ".*/confirmation.*"
      extract:
        order_number:
          selector: "#order-number"
      next: end

docs.title: Agent-Defined Intents
docs.text:
Agents can define intents during a session:

define add_to_wishlist:
  description: "Add product to wishlist"
  steps:
    - click "Add to Wishlist" or click "♡"
    - wait visible { text_contains: [added, saved] }
  success:
    - text_contains: [added, saved]

Usage: 

> add_to_wishlist
ok add_to_wishlist

docs.title: Session Management
docs.text:
# List session intents
intents --session

# Remove intent
undefine add_to_wishlist

# Export to file
export add_to_wishlist --out ~/.oryn/intents/wishlist.yaml

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
# ~/.oryn/config.yaml

intent_engine:
  resolution:
    tier_priority: [user, pack, core, builtin]
    allow_discovered: true

  execution:
    default_timeout: 30s
    step_timeout: 10s
    max_retries: 3
    retry_delay: 1s

  verification:
    verify_success: true
    verify_failure: true

  logging:
    log_actions: true
    redact_sensitive: true

docs.title: Intent Language
docs.text: The Oryn Intent Language (OIL) is a token-efficient, human-readable protocol designed specifically for AI agents to control web browsers.

docs.title: Design Philosophy
docs.text: OIL is built on four foundational principles:

docs.title: Forgiving Syntax
docs.text:
Multiple syntactic variations are accepted for the same action. The parser prioritizes understanding agent intent over enforcing rigid formatting rules.

# All of these work:
click 5
CLICK 5
Click 5

click "Sign in"
click 'Sign in'
click Sign in

docs.title: Semantic Targeting
docs.text:
Agents can reference elements by meaning rather than implementation details:

type email "user@test.com"      # By role
click "Sign in"                  # By text
click submit                     # By role
click css(".btn-primary")        # By selector (fallback)

docs.title: Token Efficiency
docs.text:
Every character counts in an agent's context window. OIL minimizes verbosity while maximizing expressiveness:

# Compact observation format
@ github.com/login "Sign in"
[1] input/email "Username" {required}
[2] input/password "Password" {required}
[3] button/submit "Sign in" {primary}

docs.title: Human Readability
docs.text: Commands and responses are designed to be immediately comprehensible to human operators.

docs.title: General Format
docs.text:
command [target] [arguments] [--options]
  • Command: The action to perform (case-insensitive)
  • Target: Element identifier (ID, text, role, or selector)
  • Arguments: Additional parameters (strings in quotes)
  • Options: Flags prefixed with --

docs.title: Target Resolution
docs.text:
Oryn supports multiple targeting strategies:

Strategy Syntax Example ID Numeric click 5 Text Quoted string click "Sign in" Role Role name type email "user@test.com" Selector css() or xpath() click css(".btn") Relational near, inside, after click "Edit" near "Item 1"

docs.title: String Handling
docs.text:
Strings can use single or double quotes interchangeably:

type 1 "hello world"
type 1 'hello world'

Single words without spaces may omit quotes:

type email user@test.com

docs.title: Navigation Commands
docs.text: Command Description Example goto <url> Navigate to URL goto github.com back Go back in history back forward Go forward in history forward refresh Reload page refresh url Get current URL url

docs.title: Observation Commands
docs.text: Command Description Example observe Scan and list elements observe observe --full Include selectors and positions observe --full observe --near "text" Filter by proximity observe --near "Login" text Get page text content text title Get page title title screenshot Capture screenshot screenshot

docs.title: Action Commands
docs.text: Command Description Example click <target> Click element click 5 click <target> --double Double-click click 5 --double click <target> --right Right-click click 5 --right type <target> <text> Type into input type 1 "hello" type <target> <text> --enter Type and press Enter type 1 "hello" --enter clear <target> Clear input field clear 1 press <key> Press keyboard key press Enter select <target> <value> Select dropdown option select 3 "Option 1" check <target> Check checkbox check 5 uncheck <target> Uncheck checkbox uncheck 5 hover <target> Hover over element hover 3 focus <target> Focus element focus 1 scroll [direction] [amount] Scroll viewport scroll down 500

docs.title: Wait Commands
docs.text: Command Description Example wait load Wait for page load wait load wait idle Wait for network idle wait idle wait visible <target> Wait for visibility wait visible "Success" wait hidden <target> Wait for element to hide wait hidden "Loading" wait url <pattern> Wait for URL match wait url "/dashboard"

docs.title: Intent Commands
docs.text: Command Description Example login <user> <pass> Execute login login "me@test.com" "pass" search <query> Execute search search "rust programming" accept_cookies Dismiss cookie banner accept_cookies dismiss_popups Close modal dialogs dismiss_popups fill_form <data> Fill multiple fields fill_form {...} submit_form Submit current form submit_form

docs.title: Success Responses
docs.text:
ok <command> [details]

[response data]

docs.title: Observation Format
docs.text:
@ domain.com/path "Page Title"

[id] type/role "text" {modifiers}

# patterns
- pattern_name: field=[id] ...

Element Types: input, button, link, select, textarea, checkbox, radio, generic

Element Roles: email, password, search, tel, url, username, submit, primary, generic

Modifiers: {required}, {disabled}, {readonly}, {checked}, {primary}, {focused}

docs.title: Error Responses
docs.text:
error <command>: <message>

# hint
<recovery suggestion>

docs.title: Change Notation
docs.text:
Symbol Meaning + Element appeared - Element disappeared ~ Element/URL changed @ Page navigated

Example:

ok click 3

# changes
~ url: /login → /dashboard
+ [1] nav "Dashboard"
- [3] button "Sign in"

docs.title: Level 1: Direct Commands
docs.text:
Operate on element IDs with no ambiguity:

click 5
type 3 "hello"
check 7

docs.title: Level 2: Semantic Commands
docs.text:
Operate on roles or text; Oryn resolves to IDs:

click "Sign in"
type email "user@test.com"
check "Remember me"

docs.title: Level 3: Intent Commands
docs.text:
High-level intents that execute multiple actions:

login "user@test.com" "password123"
search "rust programming"
dismiss popups
accept cookies

docs.title: Roles
docs.text: email, password, search, submit, username, phone, url

docs.title: Directions
docs.text: up, down, left, right, top, bottom

docs.title: Conditions
docs.text: visible, hidden, exists, gone, idle, load

docs.title: Modifiers
docs.text: near, after, before, inside, contains

docs.title: Key Names
docs.text: Enter, Tab, Escape, Space, Backspace, Delete, ArrowUp, ArrowDown, ArrowLeft, ArrowRight, Home, End, PageUp, PageDown, F1-F12, Control, Shift, Alt, Meta

docs.title: Scanner Protocol
docs.text: The Universal Scanner Protocol defines the interface between Oryn backends and the JavaScript scanner that runs inside web browsers.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The scanner is the architectural keystone of Oryn. All three backends inject the identical JavaScript into their browser contexts, guaranteeing consistent behavior.

docs.title: Design Goals
docs.text: Goal Description Universality Same protocol across WebKit, Chromium, and browser extensions Completeness Handles all element types, actions, and edge cases Efficiency Minimal data transfer, incremental updates Debuggability Clear errors, predictable structure

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text: graph LR     subgraph Backend         A[oryn-h] -->|CDP| D[Scanner]         B[oryn-e] -->|WebDriver| D         C[oryn-r] -->|WebSocket| D     end      subgraph Browser         D --> E[DOM]     end

docs.title: Request Structure
docs.text:
{
  "cmd": "command_name",
  // command-specific parameters
}

docs.title: Response Structure
docs.text:
{
  "ok": true,
  "data": {
    // command-specific response data
  },
  "timing": {
    "start": 1234567890,
    "end": 1234567891
  }
}

docs.title: Error Response
docs.text:
{
  "ok": false,
  "error": "Error message",
  "code": "ERROR_CODE"
}

docs.title: scan
docs.text:
Scan the page and return all interactive elements.

Request:

{
  "cmd": "scan",
  "max_elements": 200,
  "include_hidden": false,
  "viewport_only": false
}

Response:

{
  "ok": true,
  "data": {
    "page": {
      "url": "https://example.com/login",
      "title": "Sign In",
      "viewport": { "width": 1920, "height": 1080 },
      "scroll": { "x": 0, "y": 0, "maxX": 0, "maxY": 500 }
    },
    "elements": [
      {
        "id": 1,
        "type": "input",
        "role": "email",
        "tag": "input",
        "text": "Email address",
        "selector": "#email",
        "xpath": "//input[@id='email']",
        "rect": { "x": 100, "y": 200, "width": 300, "height": 40 },
        "attributes": { "type": "email", "required": true },
        "state": { "visible": true, "enabled": true, "focused": false }
      }
    ],
    "patterns": {
      "login_form": {
        "email": 1,
        "password": 2,
        "submit": 3
      }
    },
    "meta": {
      "total_scanned": 150,
      "interactive_found": 10,
      "scan_time_ms": 45
    }
  }
}

docs.title: click
docs.text:
Click an element by ID.

Request:

{
  "cmd": "click",
  "id": 5,
  "button": "left",
  "click_count": 1,
  "force": false,
  "scroll_into_view": true
}

Response:

{
  "ok": true,
  "data": {
    "action": "click",
    "target": { "id": 5, "selector": "#submit-btn" },
    "coordinates": { "x": 450, "y": 300 },
    "navigation_triggered": true
  }
}

docs.title: type
docs.text:
Type text into an element.

Request:

{
  "cmd": "type",
  "id": 1,
  "text": "user@example.com",
  "clear": true,
  "delay": 0
}

Response:

{
  "ok": true,
  "data": {
    "action": "type",
    "target": { "id": 1 },
    "text": "user@example.com",
    "final_value": "user@example.com"
  }
}

docs.title: select
docs.text:
Select an option in a dropdown.

Request:

{
  "cmd": "select",
  "id": 3,
  "value": "option1"
}

Response:

{
  "ok": true,
  "data": {
    "selected_value": "option1",
    "selected_text": "Option 1",
    "previous_value": "option2"
  }
}

docs.title: scroll
docs.text:
Scroll the viewport or a container.

Request:

{
  "cmd": "scroll",
  "direction": "down",
  "amount": 500,
  "behavior": "instant"
}

Response:

{
  "ok": true,
  "data": {
    "scroll_position": { "x": 0, "y": 500 },
    "max_scroll": { "x": 0, "y": 2000 }
  }
}

docs.title: wait_for
docs.text:
Wait for a condition to be true.

Request:

{
  "cmd": "wait_for",
  "condition": "visible",
  "selector": "#success-message",
  "timeout": 30000
}

Response:

{
  "ok": true,
  "data": {
    "condition_met": true,
    "wait_time_ms": 1500
  }
}

docs.title: execute
docs.text:
Execute arbitrary JavaScript.

Request:

{
  "cmd": "execute",
  "script": "return document.title;",
  "args": []
}

Response:

{
  "ok": true,
  "data": {
    "result": "Page Title"
  }
}

docs.title: Types
docs.text: Type Description input Text input, email, password, tel, url, number button Button elements and input type=button/submit link Anchor elements with href select Dropdown/select elements textarea Multi-line text input checkbox Checkbox inputs radio Radio button inputs generic Other interactive elements

docs.title: Roles
docs.text:
Roles are inferred from type attributes, autocomplete hints, labels, and context:

Role Detection Signals email type=email, autocomplete=email, label contains "email" password type=password, autocomplete=*password search type=search, role=search, label contains "search" tel type=tel, autocomplete=tel url type=url, label contains "website/url" username autocomplete=username, label contains "username" submit type=submit, button in form context

docs.title: Modifiers
docs.text: Modifier Meaning required Field is required disabled Element is disabled readonly Input is read-only hidden Element is hidden primary Primary/prominent action checked Checkbox/radio is checked focused Element has keyboard focus

docs.title: Pattern Detection
docs.text: The scanner automatically identifies common UI patterns:

docs.title: Login Form
docs.text:
{
  "login_form": {
    "email": 1,
    "password": 2,
    "submit": 3,
    "remember": 4
  }
}

docs.title: Search Form
docs.text:
{
  "search_form": {
    "input": 5,
    "submit": 6
  }
}

docs.title: Cookie Banner
docs.text:
{
  "cookie_banner": {
    "container": "#cookie-notice",
    "accept": 7,
    "reject": 8
  }
}

docs.title: Pagination
docs.text:
{
  "pagination": {
    "prev": 10,
    "next": 11,
    "pages": [12, 13, 14, 15]
  }
}

docs.title: Error Codes
docs.text: Code Description Recovery Strategy ELEMENT_NOT_FOUND Element ID doesn't exist Run scan to refresh ELEMENT_STALE Element removed from DOM Run scan to refresh ELEMENT_NOT_VISIBLE Element exists but hidden Scroll or wait ELEMENT_DISABLED Element is disabled Wait for enabled state ELEMENT_NOT_INTERACTABLE Cannot interact (covered) Use force option SELECTOR_INVALID CSS selector syntax error Fix selector TIMEOUT Operation timed out Increase timeout NAVIGATION_ERROR Navigation failed Check URL/network SCRIPT_ERROR JavaScript execution error Check script syntax

docs.title: Map Creation
docs.text: When scan is called: 1. Previous element map is cleared 2. DOM is traversed for interactive elements 3. New IDs are assigned sequentially 4. Element references are stored

docs.title: Map Staleness
docs.text: The element map becomes stale when: - Page navigation occurs - DOM is modified by JavaScript - AJAX updates content

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Always scan before starting a new task
  • Re-scan after navigation
  • Re-scan after actions that modify content
  • Don't cache element IDs across page loads

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: Welcome to Oryn! This section will help you get up and running with the browser designed for AI agents.

docs.title: What is Oryn?
docs.text:
Oryn (Open Runtime for Intentful Navigation) is a browser automation system designed specifically for AI agents. Traditional approaches force agents into unnatural workflows:

  • Screenshot/Vision: Expensive inference, unreliable text extraction
  • HTML Parsing: Thousands of tokens of irrelevant markup
  • Function Calls: Rigid schemas, no tolerance for variation

Oryn provides a semantic intent language that matches how agents think about web interaction.

docs.title: The Unified CLI
docs.text:
Oryn provides a single binary that adapts to any environment:

# Headless Mode (Cloud/CI)
oryn headless

# Embedded Mode (IoT/Edge)
oryn embedded --driver-url http://localhost:8080

# Remote Mode (Debug/Assistance)
oryn remote --port 9001

docs.title: Semantic Observations
docs.text:
Instead of raw HTML, agents see structured, labeled elements:

@ github.com/login "Sign in to GitHub"
[1] input/email "Username or email" {required}
[2] input/password "Password" {required}
[3] button/submit "Sign in" {primary}

docs.title: Intent Commands
docs.text:
Agents express actions naturally:

type email "user@example.com"
click "Sign in"

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• :material-download:{ .lg .middle } Installation

    Build Oryn from source and verify your installation.

    :octicons-arrow-right-24: Installation Guide

  • :material-rocket-launch:{ .lg .middle } Quick Start

    Run your first web automation in minutes.

    :octicons-arrow-right-24: Quick Start

  • :material-console:{ .lg .middle } CLI Reference

    Complete command-line documentation.

    :octicons-arrow-right-24: CLI Reference

docs.title: Choose Your Mode
docs.text:
Mode When to Use Headless (oryn headless) Cloud automation, CI/CD, web scraping Embedded (oryn embedded) IoT devices, containers, edge computing Remote (oryn remote) User assistance, debugging, authenticated sessions

All modes share the same protocol and behavior—agents can switch modes without changing their logic.

docs.title: CLI Reference
docs.text: Complete reference for the oryn command-line interface.

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text: oryn <MODE> [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Headless Mode
docs.text:
oryn headless [OPTIONS]

Run Oryn with a headless Chromium browser. Best for cloud automation, CI/CD, and web scraping.

Options:

Option Default Description --chrome-path <PATH> auto-detect Path to Chrome/Chromium executable --user-data-dir <DIR> temp Chrome user data directory --headless true Run in headless mode (use --no-headless for visible browser) --disable-gpu false Disable GPU acceleration --window-size <WxH> 1920x1080 Browser window size

Example:

oryn headless --no-headless --window-size 1280x720

docs.title: Embedded Mode
docs.text:
oryn embedded [OPTIONS]

Run Oryn with WPE WebKit via WebDriver. Best for IoT devices, containers, and edge computing.

Options:

Option Default Description --driver-url <URL> http://localhost:8080 WebDriver server URL

Example:

oryn embedded --driver-url http://localhost:9515

docs.title: Remote Mode
docs.text:
oryn remote [OPTIONS]

Run Oryn as a WebSocket server that connects to a browser extension. Best for user assistance, debugging, and authenticated sessions.

Options:

Option Default Description --port <PORT> 9001 WebSocket server port --host <HOST> 127.0.0.1 Host to bind to

Example:

oryn remote --port 9001 --host 0.0.0.0

docs.title: Global Options
docs.text: Option Description --help, -h Show help message --version, -V Show version information --config <FILE> Path to configuration file --log-level <LEVEL> Log level: error, warn, info, debug, trace

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: Variable Description RUST_LOG Set log level (e.g., RUST_LOG=debug) CHROME_PATH Path to Chrome executable ORYN_CONFIG Path to configuration file

docs.title: REPL Commands
docs.text: Once Oryn is running, you enter the Intent Language REPL. See the Intent Commands Reference for complete command documentation.

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: Command Description Example goto <url> Navigate to URL goto google.com observe / scan List interactive elements observe click <target> Click an element click 5 or click "Login" type <target> <text> Type into input type 1 "hello" scroll [direction] [amount] Scroll the page scroll down 500 wait <condition> Wait for condition wait visible "Success" login <user> <pass> Execute login intent login "me@example.com" "pass" search <query> Execute search intent search "rust programming" accept_cookies Dismiss cookie banner accept_cookies exit Exit Oryn exit

docs.title: Exit Codes
docs.text: Code Meaning 0 Success 1 General error 2 Invalid arguments 3 Browser launch failed 4 Connection failed

docs.title: Configuration File
docs.text:
Oryn can be configured via a YAML file:

# ~/.oryn/config.yaml

intent_engine:
  default_timeout: 30s
  step_timeout: 10s
  max_retries: 3

logging:
  log_actions: true
  redact_sensitive: true

packs:
  auto_load: true
  pack_paths:
    - ~/.oryn/packs

See Configuration Reference for all options.

docs.title: Basic Web Scraping
docs.text:
oryn headless << 'EOF'
goto example.com
observe
click "More information..."
observe
extract links
exit
EOF

docs.title: Login Automation
docs.text:
oryn headless << 'EOF'
goto myapp.com/login
login "user@example.com" "password123"
observe
exit
EOF

docs.title: CI/CD Testing
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
set -e

# Start Oryn and run test script
oryn headless < tests/e2e/login-test.oil

echo "Test passed!"

docs.title: Remote Assistance
docs.text:
# Terminal 1: Start server
oryn remote --port 9001

# User: Opens browser with extension and connects

# Terminal 1: Now control user's browser
> goto myapp.com
> observe
> click "Help"

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This guide covers how to build and install Oryn from source.

docs.title: Required
docs.text:
• Rust Toolchain: Version 1.70 or later 
    curl --proto '=https' --tlsv1.2 -sSf https://sh.rustup.rs | sh

docs.title: Mode-Specific Requirements
docs.text:
Headless Mode (oryn-h)Embedded Mode (oryn-e)Remote Mode (oryn-r)
  • Chromium Browser: Google Chrome or Chromium installed
  • RAM: ~300MB+ available
  • Works on Linux, macOS, Windows
# Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt install chromium-browser

# macOS (Chrome is typically pre-installed or download from google.com/chrome)

# Verify installation
which chromium-browser || which google-chrome
  • WPE WebKit/COG: Linux only
  • RAM: ~50MB available
  • Best for IoT and edge devices
# Ubuntu/Debian (requires additional repos for WPE)
sudo apt install cog libwpewebkit-1.0-dev
  • Browser Extension: Chrome or Firefox
  • WebSocket: Network connectivity between CLI and browser
  • Works on any system with a modern browser

docs.title: Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/dragonscale/oryn.git
cd oryn

docs.title: Build the Unified Binary
docs.text:
cargo build --release -p oryn

The binary will be available at target/release/oryn.

docs.title: Install (Optional)
docs.text:
# Copy to a directory in your PATH
sudo cp target/release/oryn /usr/local/bin/

# Or add to PATH
export PATH="$PATH:$(pwd)/target/release"

docs.title: Check Version
docs.text: oryn --version

docs.title: Test Headless Mode
docs.text:
oryn headless
# You should see the Oryn REPL prompt
> goto example.com
> observe
> exit

docs.title: Run Tests
docs.text:
# Run the full test suite
./scripts/run-tests.sh

# Run E2E tests (requires Docker)
./scripts/run-e2e-tests.sh --quick

docs.title: Docker Installation
docs.text:
Oryn provides Docker images for each mode:

# Headless mode
docker pull dragonscale/oryn-h:latest
docker run -it dragonscale/oryn-h

# Embedded mode (Debian)
docker pull dragonscale/oryn-e-debian:latest

# Embedded mode (Weston compositor)
docker run --privileged dragonscale/oryn-e-weston

docs.title: Browser Extension (Remote Mode)
docs.text:
For remote mode, install the Oryn browser extension:

  1. Navigate to chrome://extensions/ (Chrome) or about:addons (Firefox)
  2. Enable "Developer mode"
  3. Click "Load unpacked" and select the extension/ directory from the Oryn repo
  4. Start the remote server: 
    oryn remote --port 9001
  5. Click the Oryn extension icon to connect

docs.title: Chromium Not Found
docs.text:
If headless mode fails to find Chrome:

# Set the Chrome path explicitly
export CHROME_PATH=/path/to/chrome
oryn headless

docs.title: Build Errors
docs.text:
Ensure you have the latest Rust toolchain:

rustup update
cargo clean
cargo build --release -p oryn

docs.title: Permission Issues on Linux
docs.text:
If you see permission errors:

# Ensure your user can access the browser
sudo usermod -aG video $USER
# Log out and back in

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: Once installed, proceed to the Quick Start guide to run your first automation.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: This guide will have you running your first web automation with Oryn in minutes.

docs.title: Starting Oryn
docs.text:
Launch Oryn in headless mode:

oryn headless

You'll see the Oryn REPL prompt:

Oryn v1.0.0 - Headless Mode
Browser ready.
>

docs.title: Navigate to a Page
docs.text:
> goto example.com
ok goto https://example.com

# changes
@ example.com "Example Domain"

docs.title: Observe the Page
docs.text:
The observe command (or scan) shows all interactive elements:

> observe

@ example.com "Example Domain"
[1] link "More information..." {external}

# patterns
(none detected)

Each element has: - Numeric ID ([1]) for targeting - Type (link, input, button, etc.) - Text (visible or accessible label) - Modifiers ({required}, {disabled}, {primary}, etc.)

docs.title: Click an Element
docs.text:
> click 1
ok click [1]

# changes
~ url: example.com → www.iana.org/help/example-domains

docs.title: Form Interaction Example
docs.text:
Let's navigate to a login page and interact with it:

> goto github.com/login
ok goto https://github.com/login

> observe

@ github.com/login "Sign in to GitHub"
[1] input/email "Username or email address" {required}
[2] input/password "Password" {required}
[3] link "Forgot password?"
[4] button/submit "Sign in" {primary}
[5] link "Create an account"

# patterns
- login_form: email=[1] password=[2] submit=[4]

docs.title: Type into Fields
docs.text:
> type 1 "myusername"
ok type [1] "myusername"

> type 2 "mypassword"
ok type [2] "••••••••"

Notice that password values are automatically masked in responses.

docs.title: Submit the Form
docs.text:
> click 4
ok click [4]

Or use semantic targeting:

> click "Sign in"
ok click [4]

docs.title: Using Intent Commands
docs.text: Oryn provides high-level intent commands that encapsulate common workflows.

docs.title: Login Intent
docs.text:
Instead of individual commands:

> login "myusername" "mypassword"
ok login

# actions
type [1] "myusername"
type [2] "••••••••"
click [4] "Sign in"
wait navigation

docs.title: Search Intent
docs.text:
> goto google.com
> search "oryn browser automation"
ok search "oryn browser automation"

# actions
type [1] "oryn browser automation"
press Enter
wait idle

docs.title: Accept Cookies
docs.text:
> accept_cookies
ok accept_cookies

# actions
click [7] "Accept All"

# changes
- cookie_banner

docs.title: Semantic Targeting
docs.text: You can target elements by text, role, or position instead of ID:

docs.title: By Text
docs.text:
> click "Sign in"
> type "Email" "user@example.com"

docs.title: By Role
docs.text:
> type email "user@example.com"
> type password "secret123"
> click submit

docs.title: Relational Targeting
docs.text:
> click "Remove" near "Item 1"
> type "Quantity" inside "Product Card" "5"

docs.title: Scrolling
docs.text:
> scroll down
> scroll down 500       # scroll 500 pixels
> scroll to "Footer"    # scroll element into view

docs.title: Waiting
docs.text:
> wait visible "Success"
> wait hidden "Loading..."
> wait idle             # wait for network to be idle
> wait load             # wait for page load

docs.title: Exiting
docs.text:
> exit
Goodbye!

docs.title: Running Scripts
docs.text:
You can run Oryn scripts from files:

# Create a script file
cat > my-script.oil << 'EOF'
goto example.com
observe
click "More information..."
observe
EOF

# Run it
oryn headless < my-script.oil

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• CLI Reference — All command-line options
  • Intent Language — Complete command syntax
  • Form Interactions — Advanced form handling
  • Custom Intents — Define your own commands

docs.title: Guides
docs.text: Practical guides for common Oryn use cases.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
These guides walk you through real-world scenarios and best practices for using Oryn effectively.

  • :material-navigation:{ .lg .middle } Basic Navigation

    Learn to navigate pages, observe elements, and interact with the web.

    :octicons-arrow-right-24: Basic Navigation

  • :material-form-textbox:{ .lg .middle } Form Interactions

    Fill forms, handle dropdowns, checkboxes, and submit data.

    :octicons-arrow-right-24: Form Interactions

  • :material-puzzle:{ .lg .middle } Custom Intents

    Define your own intent commands for repeated workflows.

    :octicons-arrow-right-24: Custom Intents

  • :material-file-document-multiple:{ .lg .middle } Multi-Page Flows

    Orchestrate workflows that span multiple pages.

    :octicons-arrow-right-24: Multi-Page Flows

  • :material-bug:{ .lg .middle } Troubleshooting

    Common issues and how to resolve them.

    :octicons-arrow-right-24: Troubleshooting

docs.title: Always Observe First
docs.text:
Before interacting with a page, run observe to get the current element IDs:

goto example.com
observe
click 1

docs.title: Re-scan After Navigation
docs.text:
Element IDs change when the page changes. Always re-scan:

click "Submit"
observe    # Re-scan to get new elements
click "Continue"

docs.title: Use Semantic Targeting
docs.text:
When possible, use text or role targeting for more robust scripts:

# Fragile: ID might change
click 5

# Robust: text is stable
click "Sign in"

# Robust: role is semantic
type email "user@test.com"

docs.title: Handle Popups Early
docs.text:
Many sites show cookie banners or modals. Dismiss them first:

goto example.com
accept_cookies
dismiss_popups
observe

docs.title: Basic Navigation
docs.text: This guide covers the fundamentals of navigating web pages with Oryn.

docs.title: Using goto
docs.text:
Navigate to any URL:

> goto google.com
ok goto https://google.com

The protocol (https://) is automatically added if omitted.

docs.title: Full URLs
docs.text:
You can specify the full URL:

> goto https://github.com/login
ok goto https://github.com/login

docs.title: Relative Paths
docs.text:
After navigating to a site, you can use relative paths:

> goto example.com
> goto /about
ok goto https://example.com/about

docs.title: Go Back
docs.text:
> back
ok back
@ example.com "Previous Page"

docs.title: Go Forward
docs.text:
> forward
ok forward
@ example.com "Next Page"

docs.title: Refresh
docs.text:
> refresh
ok refresh

Use refresh --hard to clear cache:

> refresh --hard
ok refresh (cache cleared)

docs.title: Observing Pages
docs.text: The observe command (alias: scan) is fundamental to understanding what's on a page.

docs.title: Basic Observation
docs.text:
> observe

@ github.com/login "Sign in to GitHub"
[1] input/email "Username or email address" {required}
[2] input/password "Password" {required}
[3] link "Forgot password?"
[4] button/submit "Sign in" {primary}
[5] link "Create an account"

# patterns
- login_form: email=[1] password=[2] submit=[4]

docs.title: Understanding the Output
docs.text:
Page Header: 

@ github.com/login "Sign in to GitHub"
Shows the current URL and page title.

Elements: 

[1] input/email "Username or email address" {required}
- [1] — Numeric ID for targeting - input — Element type - email — Semantic role - "Username..." — Visible text/label - {required} — State modifier

Patterns: 

# patterns
- login_form: email=[1] password=[2] submit=[4]
Detected UI patterns with element references.

docs.title: Observation Options
docs.text:
Full details: 

> observe --full

@ github.com/login "Sign in to GitHub"
[1] input/email "Username or email address" {required}
    selector: #login_field
    xpath: //input[@id='login_field']
    rect: x=450 y=200 w=300 h=40

Filter by proximity: 

> observe --near "Sign in"

[4] button/submit "Sign in" {primary}
[5] link "Create an account"

Minimal output: 

> observe --minimal

@ github.com/login
Interactive elements: 5
Patterns: login_form

docs.title: By ID
docs.text:
The fastest and most precise method:

> click 4
ok click [4] "Sign in"

docs.title: By Text
docs.text:
More robust across page changes:

> click "Sign in"
ok click [4] "Sign in"

Text matching is case-insensitive and uses partial matching by default.

docs.title: By Role
docs.text:
For semantic targeting:

> click submit
ok click [4] "Sign in"

docs.title: Click Options
docs.text:
Double-click: 

> click 5 --double
ok double-click [5]

Right-click: 

> click 5 --right
ok right-click [5]

Force click (even if covered): 

> click 5 --force
ok click [5] (forced)

docs.title: Direction Scrolling
docs.text:
> scroll down
> scroll down 500    # 500 pixels
> scroll up
> scroll left
> scroll right

docs.title: Page Scrolling
docs.text:
> scroll page down   # One page height
> scroll page up

docs.title: Scroll to Element
docs.text:
> scroll to "Footer"
ok scroll to [15]

docs.title: Scroll to Bottom/Top
docs.text:
> scroll bottom
> scroll top

docs.title: Current URL
docs.text:
> url
https://example.com/about

docs.title: Page Title
docs.text:
> title
About Us - Example Company

docs.title: Page Text
docs.text:

[Full text content of the page]

docs.title: Extract Links
docs.text:
> extract links
[1] https://example.com/home "Home"
[2] https://example.com/about "About"
[3] https://example.com/contact "Contact"

docs.title: Wait for Page Load
docs.text:
> wait load
ok wait load (1.2s)

docs.title: Wait for Network Idle
docs.text:
> wait idle
ok wait idle (2.3s)

docs.title: Wait for Element Visibility
docs.text:
> wait visible "Success"
ok wait visible "Success" (1.5s)

docs.title: Wait for Element to Disappear
docs.text:
> wait hidden "Loading..."
ok wait hidden "Loading..." (3.2s)

docs.title: Wait for URL Change
docs.text:
> wait url "/dashboard"
ok wait url "/dashboard" (2.1s)

docs.title: Custom Timeout
docs.text:
> wait visible "Results" --timeout 60s
ok wait visible "Results" (45.3s)

docs.title: Capture Full Page
docs.text:
> screenshot
ok screenshot saved to ./screenshot.png

docs.title: Specify Output File
docs.text:
> screenshot --output ./my-screenshot.png
ok screenshot saved to ./my-screenshot.png

docs.title: Capture Specific Element
docs.text:
> screenshot --element 5
ok screenshot saved to ./screenshot.png

docs.title: Basic Page Exploration
docs.text:
goto example.com
observe
click "About"
observe
back
observe

docs.title: Handling Cookie Banners
docs.text:
goto example.com
accept_cookies    # Built-in intent
observe

docs.title: Navigating with Pagination
docs.text:
goto example.com/products
observe

# Next page
click "Next"
observe

# Previous page
click "Previous"
observe

docs.title: Scrolling to Load Content
docs.text:
goto example.com/infinite-scroll
observe

scroll down 500
wait idle
observe     # New elements loaded

scroll down 500
wait idle
observe     # More elements loaded

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Always observe after navigation — Element IDs change between pages

  2. Use semantic targeting when possible — More resilient to page changes

  3. Handle popups early — Cookie banners and modals can block interaction

  4. Wait for conditions — Don't assume instant page loads

  5. Re-scan after dynamic updates — AJAX content changes the element map

docs.title: Custom Intents
docs.text: This guide explains how to define your own intent commands for repeated workflows.

docs.title: Why Custom Intents?
docs.text:
Custom intents let you:

  • Encapsulate repeated workflows into single commands
  • Share automation patterns across sessions
  • Build site-specific automation libraries
  • Create semantic commands for your use case

docs.title: Defining an Intent
docs.text:
Use the define command to create a session-scoped intent:

define add_to_cart:
  description: "Add current product to shopping cart"
  steps:
    - click "Add to Cart" or click "Add to Basket"
    - wait visible { text_contains: [added, cart] }
  success:
    - text_contains: [added, cart, basket]

docs.title: Using the Intent
docs.text:
> goto example.com/products/widget
> add_to_cart
ok add_to_cart

# actions
click [5] "Add to Cart"
wait visible "Added to cart"

docs.title: Step Syntax
docs.text:
Steps support a simplified syntax:

Multiple fallback targets: 

steps:
  - click "Add to Cart" or click "Buy Now" or click "Add"

Wait conditions: 

steps:
  - wait visible "Success"
  - wait hidden "Loading"

Type shortcuts: 

steps:
  - type email "user@test.com"
  - type password "secret"

docs.title: Defining with Parameters
docs.text:
define review_product:
  description: "Submit a product review"
  parameters:
    - rating: number, required
    - text: string, required
  steps:
    - click "Write a Review"
    - wait visible review_form
    - click star[$rating]
    - type review_text $text
    - click "Submit Review"
  success:
    - text_contains: "review submitted"

docs.title: Using Parameters
docs.text:
> review_product --rating 5 --text "Excellent product!"
ok review_product

# actions
click [7] "Write a Review"
wait visible review_form
click [12] (5 stars)
type [15] "Excellent product!"
click [18] "Submit Review"

docs.title: Parameter Types
docs.text: Type Description Example string Text value --name "John" number Numeric value --rating 5 boolean True/false --subscribe true object JSON object --data '{"a": 1}' array JSON array --items '["a", "b"]'

docs.title: YAML Intent Definitions
docs.text: For persistent intents, create YAML files in ~/.oryn/intents/:

docs.title: Basic Intent
docs.text:
# ~/.oryn/intents/subscribe_newsletter.yaml

intent: subscribe_newsletter
version: "1.0"
description: "Subscribe to the site newsletter"

steps:
  - action: click
    target: { text_contains: ["Subscribe", "Newsletter"] }

  - action: wait
    condition: { visible: { text_contains: "email" } }

  - action: type
    target: { role: email }
    text: $email

  - action: click
    target: { role: submit }

success:
  conditions:
    - text_contains: ["thank you", "subscribed", "confirmed"]

docs.title: Intent with Fallbacks
docs.text:
# ~/.oryn/intents/dismiss_cookie.yaml

intent: dismiss_cookie
version: "1.0"
description: "Dismiss cookie consent with fallbacks"

steps:
  - action: click
    target: { text: "Accept All" }
    on_error:
      - action: click
        target: { text: "Accept" }
      - action: click
        target: { text: "OK" }
      - action: click
        target: { text: "Got it" }

docs.title: Intent with Conditions
docs.text:
intent: checkout_if_cart
version: "1.0"
description: "Proceed to checkout if cart has items"

steps:
  - action: observe
    store: page_state

  - branch:
      if: { pattern_exists: empty_cart }
      then:
        - action: error
          message: "Cart is empty"
      else:
        - action: click
          target: { text: "Checkout" }

        - action: wait
          condition: { url_contains: "/checkout" }

docs.title: Site-Specific Packs
docs.text: Organize intents into site-specific packs:

docs.title: Pack Structure
docs.text:
~/.oryn/packs/
└── amazon.com/
    ├── pack.yaml
    ├── patterns.yaml
    └── intents/
        ├── add_to_cart.yaml
        ├── checkout.yaml
        └── track_order.yaml

docs.title: Pack Metadata
docs.text:
# pack.yaml

pack: amazon.com
version: "1.0.0"
description: "Intent pack for Amazon"

domains:
  - amazon.com
  - www.amazon.com

auto_load:
  - "https://amazon.com/*"
  - "https://www.amazon.com/*"

docs.title: Site-Specific Patterns
docs.text:
# patterns.yaml

patterns:
  product_page:
    detection:
      url_contains: "/dp/"
    elements:
      title:
        selector: "#productTitle"
      price:
        selector: ".a-price-whole"
      add_to_cart:
        selector: "#add-to-cart-button"
      buy_now:
        selector: "#buy-now-button"

  cart:
    detection:
      url_contains: "/cart"
    elements:
      checkout:
        selector: "#sc-buy-box-ptc-button"
      quantity_inputs:
        selector: ".sc-quantity-textfield"

docs.title: Site Intent
docs.text:
# intents/add_to_cart.yaml

intent: add_to_cart
version: "1.0"
pack: amazon.com

triggers:
  patterns:
    - product_page
  urls:
    - "*/dp/*"

parameters:
  - name: quantity
    type: number
    default: 1

steps:
  - branch:
      if: { gt: [$quantity, 1] }
      then:
        - action: select
          target: { id_contains: "quantity" }
          value: $quantity

  - action: click
    target: { pattern: product_page.add_to_cart }

  - action: wait
    condition:
      any:
        - text_contains: "Added to Cart"
        - url_contains: "/cart"

success:
  conditions:
    - text_contains: ["Added to Cart", "added to your"]

docs.title: List All Intents
docs.text:
> intents
Built-in intents:
  - login
  - logout
  - search
  - accept_cookies
  - dismiss_popups
  - fill_form
  - submit_form
  - scroll_to

Loaded intents:
  - subscribe_newsletter (user)
  - add_to_cart (amazon.com)

Session intents:
  - review_product

docs.title: List Session Intents
docs.text:
> intents --session
Session intents:
  - review_product (defined 5 mins ago)
  - quick_checkout (defined 2 mins ago)

docs.title: Remove Session Intent
docs.text:
> undefine review_product
ok undefine review_product

docs.title: Clear All Session Intents
docs.text:
> intents --clear-session
ok cleared 2 session intents

docs.title: Export to File
docs.text:
> export review_product --out ~/.oryn/intents/review_product.yaml
ok export review_product

# written
~/.oryn/intents/review_product.yaml

The exported intent will be automatically loaded on future sessions.

docs.title: 1. Use Descriptive Names
docs.text:
# Good
intent: add_product_to_wishlist

# Avoid
intent: apw

docs.title: 2. Include Descriptions
docs.text:
intent: checkout_with_express
description: "Complete checkout using express/saved payment method"

docs.title: 3. Provide Fallback Targets
docs.text:
- action: click
  target: { text: "Submit Order" }
  on_error:
    - action: click
      target: { text: "Place Order" }
    - action: click
      target: { role: submit }

docs.title: 4. Verify Success
docs.text:
success:
  conditions:
    - url_contains: "/confirmation"
    - text_contains: "order confirmed"

docs.title: 5. Handle Errors Gracefully
docs.text:
failure:
  conditions:
    - text_contains: ["error", "failed", "invalid"]
  recovery:
    - action: screenshot
    - action: observe

docs.title: 6. Document Parameters
docs.text:
parameters:
  - name: shipping_speed
    type: string
    required: false
    default: "standard"
    description: "Shipping speed: standard, express, or overnight"

docs.title: Example: Complete Checkout Intent
docs.text:
intent: complete_checkout
version: "1.0"
description: "Complete checkout with shipping and payment"

parameters:
  - name: shipping
    type: object
    required: true
    description: "Shipping address object"
  - name: payment
    type: object
    required: true
    description: "Payment details object"

flow:
  start: cart
  pages:
    - name: cart
      url_pattern: ".*/cart.*"
      steps:
        - action: click
          target: { text: "Proceed to Checkout" }
      next: shipping

    - name: shipping
      url_pattern: ".*/checkout/shipping.*"
      steps:
        - action: fill_form
          data: $shipping
        - action: click
          target: { text: "Continue to Payment" }
      next: payment

    - name: payment
      url_pattern: ".*/checkout/payment.*"
      steps:
        - action: fill_form
          data: $payment
        - action: click
          target: { text: "Place Order" }
      next: confirmation

    - name: confirmation
      url_pattern: ".*/confirmation.*"
      extract:
        order_number:
          selector: "#order-number"
        total:
          selector: ".order-total"
      next: end

success:
  conditions:
    - url_contains: "/confirmation"
  extract:
    order_number:
      from: page
      selector: "#order-number"

failure:
  conditions:
    - text_contains: ["payment declined", "error"]

docs.title: Form Interactions
docs.text: This guide covers how to interact with forms, including text inputs, dropdowns, checkboxes, and form submission.

docs.title: Basic Typing
docs.text:
> observe
[1] input/email "Email" {required}
[2] input/password "Password" {required}

> type 1 "user@example.com"
ok type [1] "user@example.com"

> type 2 "mypassword"
ok type [2] "••••••••"

Note: Password values are automatically masked in responses.

docs.title: Typing by Role
docs.text:
> type email "user@example.com"
ok type [1] "user@example.com"

> type password "mypassword"
ok type [2] "••••••••"

docs.title: Typing by Label
docs.text:
> type "Email" "user@example.com"
ok type [1] "user@example.com"

docs.title: Type Options
docs.text:
Append without clearing: 

> type 1 "additional text" --append

Type and press Enter: 

> type 1 "search query" --enter

Type with delay between keys: 

> type 1 "slow typing" --delay 100

docs.title: Clearing Inputs
docs.text:
> clear 1
ok clear [1]

> click submit
ok click [9] "Submit"

Or by text:

ok click [9] "Submit"

> submit_form
ok submit_form

docs.title: The fill_form Intent
docs.text:
For filling multiple fields at once:

> fill_form {"name": "John Doe", "email": "john@example.com", "country": "us"}
ok fill_form

# filled
[1] input "Name" ← "John Doe"
[2] input "Email" ← "john@example.com"
[3] select "Country" ← "United States"

docs.text:
> fill_form {"name": "John"} --partial
ok fill_form

# filled
[1] input "Name" ← "John"

"email": no value provided
"country": no value provided

docs.title: The login Intent
docs.text:
For login forms, use the built-in login intent:

> goto example.com/login
> login "user@example.com" "password123"
ok login

# actions
type [1] "user@example.com"
type [2] "••••••••"
click [3] "Sign in"
wait navigation

# changes
~ url: /login → /dashboard
- login_form
+ user_menu

docs.title: Login Without Submitting
docs.text:
> login "user@example.com" "password123" --no-submit
ok login (not submitted)

# actions
type [1] "user@example.com"
type [2] "••••••••"

For search forms:

> goto google.com
> search "oryn browser automation"
ok search

# actions
clear [1]
type [1] "oryn browser automation"
press Enter
wait idle

ok click [5] "Edit"

docs.title: Target Inside Container
